page.title: 02COMING OF HARLOW NEW TOWN.
page.content: In 1930 Marjorie Parker moved to a farm in{Harlow},which was then a few small hamlets surounded by peaceful countryside.She remembers{Lord Silkin, the Minister of Town and Country Planning ,introducing in 1946 the{New {Towns Act}, mainly because of over- crowding and homelessness in the big cities after the war.She also recalls{ {Leah Manning},our local labour M.P. being involved in planning New Harlow. The Residents' Association strongly opposed the building of a town here . Nevertheless many workers wanted the town ,which would bring more homes and jobs .They signed a petition for a new town and after an enquiry the building of Harlow went ahead .Miss Parker also remembers Burnt Mill village ,two rows of forty houses ,being demolished in 1961 to make way for Longmans the Publishers,by the town station.
